questions.text: Which drugs is not use do detoxification of chronic alcoholics:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A. Flumazenil (Incorrect) Flumazenil is a benzodiazepine receptor antagonist. Its primary use is to reverse the effects of benzodiazepine overdose or to wake patients up after benzodiazepine sedation. While alcohol acts on similar GABA receptors as benzodiazepines, flumazenil is not indicated or effective for managing acute alcohol withdrawal symptoms. In fact, using flumazenil in alcohol withdrawal could potentially worsen symptoms or even precipitate seizures, especially if benzodiazepines have been used to manage the withdrawal. Detoxification from alcohol typically involves using benzodiazepines to manage withdrawal symptoms, not a benzodiazepine antagonist. B. Disulfiram (Correct for long-term sobriety, but not for acute detoxification) Disulfiram (Antabuse) is used in the long-term management of alcohol dependence after detoxification. It works by inhibiting the enzyme aldehyde dehydrogenase, which is responsible for breaking down acetaldehyde (a toxic byproduct of alcohol metabolism). If a person consumes alcohol while taking disulfiram, acetaldehyde builds up, leading to a highly unpleasant reaction known as the disulfiram-alcohol reaction. This reaction includes symptoms like flushing, nausea, vomiting, headache, and palpitations, serving as a deterrent to drinking. However, disulfiram is not used during the acute detoxification phase because it does not alleviate withdrawal symptoms and could worsen the patient's condition if alcohol is still in their system. C. Acamprosate (Correct for long-term sobriety, but not for acute detoxification) Acamprosate (Campral) is also used for the maintenance of abstinence from alcohol after detoxification. Its exact mechanism of action is not fully understood, but it is thought to normalize brain activity that has been altered by chronic alcohol use, particularly by modulating glutamate and GABA neurotransmitter systems. Acamprosate helps reduce cravings and the psychological discomfort associated with protracted abstinence. Like disulfiram, it is not used to manage acute withdrawal symptoms during the detoxification period itself. D. Naltrexone (Correct for long-term sobriety, but not for acute detoxification) Naltrexone is an opioid receptor antagonist used for the prevention of relapse in alcohol dependence. It works by blocking the pleasurable effects (the "high") associated with alcohol consumption by antagonizing opioid receptors that are involved in the brain's reward pathways. This helps reduce cravings and the reinforcing effects of alcohol. Naltrexone can be started during or after detoxification, but its primary role is in preventing relapse, not in actively managing the acute physical symptoms of withdrawal. It doesn't treat the acute physical symptoms of alcohol withdrawal.

questions.text: Major aim of Phase 1trial is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Phase I trials are done mainly for testing maximum tolerable dose, in-turn safety. In Phase 1 of Trial: Effects of the drug as a function of dosage are established in a small number (20-100) healthy-volunteers. Goal: To Find the maximum tolerated dose, safe clinical dosage range. Pharmacokinetics of absorption, half-life and metabolism are done. Phase -II of Clinical Trials: -Dose range - Safety - Efficacy Safety and Efficacy is determined in comparison to standard Drug or placebo ( Standard Drug> Placebo) Patients : 100-500 Duration: 2-3 years Maximum drug failure : 75% Phase II is also called as therapeutic exploratory trials .

questions.text: Which liver enzyme is elevated in Azathioprine toxicity?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Azathioprine is an immunosuppressant drug that can unfortunately cause liver damage. When this happens, several liver enzymes may be elevated. SGPT (also known as ALT) is a key indicator of liver cell damage and is commonly elevated in azathioprine toxicity. While GGT and ALP can also be elevated, particularly if there's bile duct involvement, SGPT is a primary marker for direct liver cell injury. TPMT is an enzyme involved in azathioprine's metabolism, not a marker of liver toxicity itself.

questions.text: Which is not a mechanism of bacterial resistance
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) types of bacterial resistence 1. Drug inactivation or modification: for example, enzymatic deactivation of penicillin G in some penicillin-resistant bacteria through the production of ?-lactamases. Most commonly, the protective enzymes produced by the bacterial cell will add an acetyl or phosphate group to a specific site on the antibiotic, which will reduce its ability to bind to the bacterial ribosomes and disrupt protein synthesis. 2. Alteration of target- or binding site: for example, alteration of PBP—the binding target site of penicillins—in MRSA and other penicillin-resistant bacteria. Another protective mechanism found among bacterial species is ribosomal protection proteins. These proteins protect the bacterial cell from antibiotics that target the cell's ribosomes to inhibit protein synthesis. The mechanism involves the binding of the ribosomal protection proteins to the ribosomes of the bacterial cell, which in turn changes its conformational shape. This allows the ribosomes to continue synthesizing proteins essential to the cell while preventing antibiotics from binding to the ribosome to inhibit protein synthesis. 3. Alteration of metabolic pathway: for example, some sulfonamide-resistant bacteria do not require para-aminobenzoic acid (PABA), an important precursor for the synthesis of folic acid and nucleic acids in bacteria inhibited by sulfonamides, instead, like mammalian cells, they turn to using preformed folic acid. 4. Reduced drug accumulation: by decreasing drug permeability or increasing active efflux (pumping out) of the drugs across the cell surface. These pumps within the cellular membrane of certain bacterial species are used to pump antibiotics out of the cell before they are able to do any damage. They are often activated by a specific substrate associated with an antibiotic as in fluoroquinolone resistance. 5. Ribosome splitting and recycling: for example, drug-mediated stalling of the ribosome by lincomycin and erythromycin unstalled by a heat shock protein found in Listeria monocytogenes, which is an homologous of HflX from other bacteria. Liberation of the ribosome from the drug allows further translation and consequent resistance to the drug

questions.text: A patient in ICU is currently on dopamine infusion of 8 microgram/kg/min. What are the likely effects to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A,B,D,E) Ref: KDT 7th Ed/426 Explanation: Dose-dependent effects of dopamine • At low dose (1-5 µg/kg/min): Renal vasodilatation causing increased renal blood flow, tachycardia, increased systemic vascular resistance but no effect on pulmonary vascular resistance • At moderate dose (5-10 µg/kg/min): Increased stroke volume, tachycardia, increased myocardial oxygen demand, renal vasodilatation causing increased renal blood flow, increased pulm vascular resistance • At higher dose (10-20 µg/kg/min): Increased HR, CO, PVR, increased systemic vascular resistance and increased myocardial oxygen demand

questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) • Steps of serotonin synthesis are 1. Tryptophan is convereted to tryptophan hydroxylase by hydroxylase enzyme 2. Tryptophan hydroxylase is converted into 5 hydroxytryptamine by decarboxylase enzyme

questions.text: Basiliximab mechanism of action is on-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) • Basiliximab blocks interleukin 2 receptors (CD-25) present n T lymphocytes • Uses: organ transplantation • Other drug blocking IL-2 receptor is daclizumad used for multiple scelrosis

questions.text: Which of the following drugs do not decrease bone resorption?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) • Teriparatide helps in formation of bone • Used in treatment of osteoporosis • Drugs for osteoporosis 1. Osteoclast inhibitors: bisphosphonates,calcitonin, gallium nitrate, denosumab, estrogen, raloxifene, cinacalcet 2. Osteoblast stimulators: teriparatide,abaloparatide 3. Dual mechanism: strontium ranolate

questions.text: All are true about prasugrel except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) • Prasugrel is an antiplatelet drug of class ADP receptor blocker • Other ADP receptor blockers are: 1. Irreversible blockers: ticlopidine, clopidogrel, prasugrel 2. Reversible blockers: ticagrelor, canegrelor • These drugs are used as add on drugs to aspirin in stroke and peripheral vascular disease. • Prasugrel is not used in stroke • .all these above drugs are prodrugs except canegrelor • All these drugs are oral except canegrelor • All these drugs are safe in renal failure

questions.text: Mechanism of action of curare is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) • Curare drugs block Nm receptor of acetylcholine on muscle • Hence prevent sodium influx and depolarisation of muscle

questions.text: Which of the following drug cause maximum prolactin secretion?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) • Dopamine eleased from hypothalamus act on D2 receptors on pituatry and prevent prolactin release • Hence drugs blocking D2 receptors increase prolactin release

questions.text: Pirenzepine is used in-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) • Pirenzipine is an anti muscarinic agent blocking M1 receptors .Used : peptic ulcres • Hyoscine blockrs all muscarinic receptors. Used in treatment of motion sickness, narco analysis • Atropine: used to treat bradycardia

questions.text: All of the following is true about tigecycline except-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) • Tigecycline belongs to GLYCYLCYLINE group of antibiotics • It is derived from tetracycline • Mech of action : inhibit 30s ribosome hence inhibit protein synthesis • Tigecycline is effective in cases of tetracycline resistence • It is used intravenously( not given oral due to low bioavailibitilty) • Large volume of distribution • Not metabolised by any CYP enzymes • Excreted unchanged in bile. Safe in renal failure • Used as reserve drug in resistet cases in streptococcus pyogenes, MRSA< VRSA, enterococcus fecalis

questions.text: Which of the following should be avoided in a patient who is taking tadalafil?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) • Tadalafil and sildenafil are phosphodiesterase 5 inhibitors • Cyclic GMP is degraded by phosphodiesterase 5 enzyme. • These drugs increase c-GMP hence cause vasodilatation hence used in impotence and pulmonary hypertension • Vasodilator drugs produce nitric oxide and cause increase in c-GMP . • Combined usage of vasodilators and tadalafil causes massive vasodilatation and hypotension leading to sudden death

questions.text: Which of the following drug does not act on anaerobic organism?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) • Aminoglycosides are not effective in anerobic infections and also in typhoid • Drugs effective in anerobic infections are 1. Metronidazole 2. Clindamycin 3. Cotrimoxazole 4. Cephalosporins ( II and III generation) 5. Macrolides 6. Vancomycin 7. fluroquinalones

questions.text: Mycoplasma is inherently resistant to
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) • Atypical bacteria that do not contain cell wall are : mycoplasma, chlamydia, rickettsia • Cell wall inhibitors are not effective in such bacteria • Cell wall inhibitors are: beta lactams, penicinilins, cephalosporins, monobactams, carbapenams

questions.text: Which antibiotic will act in ESBL producing Klebsiella Pneumoniae?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) • ESBL: extended spectrum beta lactamses. It is an enzyme found in bacteria like klebsiella. They degrade extended spectrum penicillin like amoxicillin, ampicillin and third generation cephalosprins • DOC for ESBL are beta lactams+ beta lactamase inhibitors • Second line is carbapenams or fourth generation cephalosporins • Third line: colistins ( polymixins)

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is centrally acting alpha-2 agonist muscle relaxant?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) • Centrally acting skeletal muscle relaxants 1. GABA A+B inhibitors : bensodiazepenes 2. GABA B agonist: baclofen 3. Alpha 2A agonist: tizanidine 4. Cholroxazone, methocarbamole, mataxolone • Used in cases of cerebral palsy, tetanus, ALS

questions.text: Which of the following drug inhibit synthesis of glucocorticoids?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) • Antiglucocorticoids 1. Inhibit secretion of ACTH from pituitary ( somatostatin analogues): octreotide, paserotide 2. Inhibit synthesis of glucocorticoids in adrenal gland: metyrapone, aminoglutethemide, ketoconazole, etomidate, mitotane, trilosane 3. Block Gluckocorticoid receptor: mifipristone

questions.text: Colchicine mechanism of action in gout?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) • Colchicine is a microtubule inhibitor by inhibiting depolymerisation of spindles • These drugs inhibit WBC migration and WBC division. Thus reduces inflammation • Uses: acute gouty arthritis, familial mediterranian fever, karyotyping

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can be used both in AIDS and Hepatitis B
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) • Drugs used in both HIV and hepatitis B are 1. Lamivudine 2. Emtricitabine 3. Tenofovir

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of apixaban?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Apixaban is an oral anticoagulant and direct inhibitor of factor Xa which is used to decrease the risk of venous thromboses, systemic embolization and stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation, and lower the risk of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolus

questions.text: A bedridden patient is suffering from catheter related UTI and pneumonia. Which of the following antibiotics can be used?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) • Bacteria causing UTI and pneumonia are resistant to beta lactams • Hence the drug of choice become beta lactams plus beta lactamase inhibitors

questions.text: Fluroquinolone with maximun bioavailability is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) • Levofloxacin has 100% oral bioavailability • Gatifloxacin has been banned due to causing hypoglycaemia • Ciprofloxacin is an CYP enzyme inhibitor • Moxifloxacin is safe in renal failure

questions.text: Mechanism of action of buspirone is?

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug used to treat SIADH
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) • SIADH: syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion • Treatment is to block ADH receptors • Examples: tolvaptan, conivaptan • Demeclocycline also blocks ADH receptors

questions.text: Drugs acting on K+ channels include
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) • Spironolactone blocks aldosterone receptors • Amiloride blocks epithelial Na+ channels • Nicorandil is K+ channel opener , used in angina • Methyl dopa is alpha 2A agonist, decreases sympathetic nervous system used to treat pregeancy hypertension • Other K+ channel openers are: minoxidil, diazoxide, hydralazine

questions.text: Imipenem, a newer antibiotic with a broad antibacterial spectrum is combined with cilastin. Which of the following is the best reason for the same?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) • Imipenem belongs to class carbapenams • It is quickly degraded by enzyme present in kidney called di hydro peptidase 1 (DHP 1) • Cilastatin inhibits DHP-1 hence makes imipenem longer acting

questions.text: A drug with high plasma protein binding property has which of the following properties?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) • Increased binding to plasma protein will decrease volume of distribution • Since plasma protein doesn’t allow movement of drug during glomerular filteration, it reduces the GFR • Tubular secretion is an active process and doesn’t depend on plasma protein binding

questions.text: Mechanism of action of oseltamivir
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) • Osteltamivir is a neuraminidase inhibitor • It is used in influenza • Treatment of influenza 1. M2 proton inhibitors: amantadine, rimantadine . given for influenza type A 2. Neuraminidase inhibitors: osteltamivir ( oral), zanamivir ( nasal), peramivir ( parenteral)

questions.text: What is the advantage of fixed dose combination of drugs?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Advantages of fixed drug combinations • Increases efficacy of drug; carbidopa – levodopa • Decreses adverse effect: cilastatin reduces nephrotoxicity of imipenem • Compliance of patient is improved as he has to take one tablet instead of two

questions.text: DOC for digitalis induced Ventricular tachycardia is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) • Lidocaine is given to treat ventricular tachycardia due to digoxin • Verapamil is contraindicated as it increases digoxin toxicity • Beta blockers is given for supraventricular tachycardia

questions.text: Carbapenem which has tendency to cause maximum seizures is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) • Imipenem belongs to class carbapenams • It is quickly degraded by enzyme present in kidney called di hydro peptidase 1 (DHP 1) • Cilastatin inhibits DHP-1 hence makes imipenem longer acting • Side effect of imipenem is seizures

questions.text: Iv mannitol is used for the treatment of?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) • IV mannitol causes osmotic diuresis • Uses: cerebral edema, acute congestive glaucoma, dialysis disequilibrium • Rapidly excreted through kidney. Hence used to treat cisplatin toxicity
